newsitem.title: USA: Banks mull finance for PDVSA Petrozuata oil deal.
newsitem.headline: Banks mull finance for PDVSA Petrozuata oil deal.

text.p: Venezuela's $2.2 billion Petrozuata oil joint venture between state-owned Petroleos de Venezuela subsidiary Maraven and Dupont Co's Conoco is winning approval among bankers who are being asked to fund more than half the deal.
But there are still concerns that Venezuela won't be able to hold up its end of the deal, banking sources said.

Petrozuata, a 50-50 joint venture, would produce, upgrade and export Venezuelan extra-heavy crude from the vast Orinoco Tar Belt. It is likely to pump about 120,000 barrels per day (bpd) of extra-heavy crude and upgrade it into 104,000 bpd of 21 API gravity "synthetic" crude for export.

Investors are keeping a close eye on the financial fortunes of Petrozuata as a barometer for the success of five other Orinoco upgrading deals with top U.S. and European companies worth an estimated $15 billion.
The project is likely to win an investment-grade rating (Triple-B or better) from at least one of the top U.S. credit-rating agencies, sources say.
"There is a very good possibility that this project will get an investment grade rating," a financial source said. "It's a good project."
The rating will determine how much of the $1.3 billion debt portion of the project can be tapped from the capital markets.
Maraven and Conoco are now courting commercial banks to complement a proposed bond offering. But with or without a strong rating, many bankers are jittery over Venezuelan sovereign risk.
"If this project was in Canada, I can say unequivocally it would be a slam-dunk," one banker said. "If there's any credit risk at all, it's with Venezuela."

Another banker echoed that concern: "There's a very recent history of exchange controls. For us, that's a very big concern. There are also political concerns, just listen to the talk of coup rumors...Looking at a 10-year window, we don't know what's going to happen."
"It's all going to boil down to how we view sovereign risk," another banker said.
Venezuela has a sovereign credit rating of Single-B from Standard & Poor's and Ba2 from Moody's, both below investment grade.
But Venezuelan risk isn't the only concern among bankers. Some worry what could happen if Dupont spins off Conoco, as Dupont officials have suggested in the past.

"What roles will Conoco and Dupont play? Who will sign the contract?" one financial source asked, alluding to the possibility that Conoco might not have the means to guarantee the loan without Dupont's financial muscle behind it.
One banker insisted that Dupont would be obliged to guarantee the debt even if it sold off Conoco.
